00013  * @file

00015  * Documentation source for NAND boot.

00018 
00019 /**
00020  * @page nand_boot Booting OCTEON from NAND Flash
00021  *
00022  * @section nand_boot_intro 1. Introduction
00023  *
00024  * Beginning with CN52XX pass 2, OCTEON chips support booting from NAND flash
00025  * instead of the normal NOR flash. NAND flash presents different technical issues
00026  * than NOR flash that substantially change the boot process. This document
00027  * describes the design and implementation of NAND boot supported by the OCTEON
00028  * SDK.
00029  *
00030  *     - @ref nand_boot_intro
00031  *     - @ref nand_boot_technical
00032  *     - @ref nand_boot_stages
00033  *     - @ref nand_boot_stage1
00034  *     - @ref nand_boot_stage2_env
00035  *     - @ref nand_boot_stage2_resp
00036  *     - @ref nand_boot_stage3_env
00037  *     - @ref nand_boot_stage3_resp
00038  *     - @ref nand_boot_final
00039  *     - @ref nand_boot_hands_on
00040  *
00041  * @section nand_boot_technical 2. Technical Differences between NAND and NOR
00042  *
00043  * A few technical differences between NAND and NOR flash cause booting to be much
00044  * different between the two. Here are some of the key points:
00045  *
00046  * - NAND does not support random access, while NOR does.  As a processor
00047  * boots it must jump to different code locations and read data from various
00048  * locations in flash.  For NOR flash, the processor can do this by
00049  * requesting individual bytes from any location in flash.  NOR bytes are
00050  * individually addressable.  NAND, on the other hand, does not support
00051  * direct addressing.  Instead the NAND flash responds to commands to read
00052  * blocks of data in a stream oriented fashion.
00053  *
00054  * - NOR flash guarantees that all blocks can be programmed without error for
00055  * a specified number of write cycles.  This allows data to be stored in NOR
00056  * flash without any error correction code.  NAND does not guarantee perfect
00057  * blocks, but instead guarantees a maximum number of bit errors per device.
00058  * Users of NAND must be able to detect and fix single bits errors.  Multiple
00059  * bit errors are unlikely, but still need to be detected.
00060  *
00061  * - NAND flash supports out of band data for error detection and correction
00062  * that doesn't fall into the normal linear memory addressing scheme.
00063  * Unlike NOR, NAND device addresses don't linearly increment and may contain
00064  * addressing holes between erase blocks.
00065  *
00066  * @section nand_boot_stages 3. OCTEON's NAND Boot Stages
00067  *
00068  * In order to properly support NAND, OCTEON uses two or three stages to
00069  * bootstrap a core into the normal ram resident bootloader. These stages are
00070  * divided up as follows:
00071  *
00072  * @subsection nand_boot_stages_s1 3.1. Stage 1 - Initial NAND
00073  *
00074  * The first stage bootloader is fetched by the OCTEON processor as soon as the
00075  * first processor comes out of reset.  These instructions are fetch from the
00076  * first page of NAND in an OCTEON proprietary ECC format.  256 bytes, or 64
00077  * instructions are fetch from NAND along with 8 bytes of ECC information. After
00078  * the ECC fixes any correctable errors, this data is cached inside the OCTEON
00079  * NAND controller.  These 64 instructions must program the NAND controller and
00080  * fetch the rest of stage 1.  If ECC fails to fix an error in this early boot
00081  * mode, OCTEON will halt execution. For this reason is it highly desirable to
00082  * keep the amount of code executing in this stage to an absolute minimum.
00083  *
00084  * @subsection nand_boot_stages_s2 3.2. Stage 2 - Memory Setup
00085  *
00086  * Since NAND flash blocks support a much lower number of write cycles
00087  * than NOR flash, parts of boot that generally require tweaks and frequent
00088  * updates have been moved into a second stage. This stage can be located
00089  * anywhere in the first 4MB of NAND. Stage 1 searches for this stage looking
00090  * for a specific header. Once loaded, this stage must setup dram.  Optionally
00091  * the second stage can load the third stage or else it can be the final stage.
00092  * To make application support easier, stage 2 normally
00093  * loads stage 3 from a JFFS2 or UBIFS filesystem.  Stage 2 supports saving its
00094  * environment to NAND, however unlike NOR flash the loading of the NAND
00095  * environment is somewhat late in the process.
00096  * 
00097  * In addition to JFFS2, UBIFS is also supported as are EXT2 and FAT for loading
00098  * a bootloader off of compact flash, USB or SATA.
00099  * 
00100  * Starting with the 2.2 SDK only OCTEON II devices are supported.  The OCTEON
00101  * CN5200 is not supported for NAND booting because of limitations of the L2
00102  * cache.
00103  *
00104  * @subsection nand_boot_stages_s3 3.3. Stage 3 - Final Bootloader
00105  *
00106  * The final stage of booting is responsible for the application visible
00107  * interface. By default this stage is a U-boot bootloader with fairly full
00108  * featured access to compact flash, USB, NAND, and PCIe. This stage can be
00109  * freely replaced with any bootloader a customer wishes. Since dram
00110  * initialization was performed in stage 2, this bootloader isn't as dependent
00111  * on board configuration as a normal NOR flash based bootloader.
00112  *
00113  * @section nand_boot_stage1 4. Details of Stage 1
00114  *
00115  * Stage 1 booting entails three logical code sections. In the first section,
00116  * OCTEON is executing directly out of NAND flash. This section must be entirely
00117  * in assembly and be as small as possible.
00118  *
00119  * -# OCTEON comes out of reset, fetching instructions from NAND block 0, page
00120  *  0.
00121  * -# Enable 64bit addressing.
00122  * -# Clear COP0 STATUS[BEV].
00123  * -# Set NAND size parameters for early boot.
00124  * -# Disable Icache prefetching.
00125  * -# Setup UART baud rate based on OCTEON's clock.
00126  * -# Print the "OCTEON NAND Boot" banner.
00127  * -# Setup L2 cache index aliasing.
00128  * -# Lock the memory where stage 1 is linked at into L2.
00129  * -# Copy stage 1 code from NAND into L2 using the stage 1 link address. Note
00130  *  that the default stage 1 link address is 0xffffffff80400000. It may be
00131  *  changed by editing the stage 1 makefile.
00132  * -# Jump into L2.
00133  *
00134  * The second section is a short amount of assembly executing from L2. This code
00135  * is simply responsible for setting up a stack and transitioning into C code.
00136  * Section 2 is the first code that is executing in an environment such that
00137  * NAND unrecoverable errors can be handled gracefully.
00138  *
00139  * -# Setup CVMSEG memory for stack space.
00140  * -# Jump into C code at main().
00141  *
00142  * The third section, written in C code is responsible for finding and loading
00143  * stage 2. Logically this section searches NAND and finds the appropriate stage
00144  * 2, loads it, and jumps to stage 2.
00145  *
00146  * -# Install exception vectors to display messages if something unexpected
00147  *  happens. This involves placing the two bootbus moveable regions on the reset
00148  *  vector and the ejtag exception vector. The exception vectors 0x0, 0x80,
00149  *  0x100, 0x180, and 0x200 are configured to jump to the stage 1 exception dump
00150  *  code. This code displays all registers to the console.
00151  * -# Setup the NAND controller to disable boot mode and switch to the normal
00152  *  command queue mode.
00153  * -# Read GPIO 0 to determine if the failsafe or normal stage 2 image should be
00154  *  loaded.
00155  * -# Search for an image and load it into L2.
00156  * -# If an image was found, jump into it. This completes stage 1 and stage 2
00157  *  takes over.
00158  * -# If an image was not found and we weren't trying to load the failsafe, try
00159  *  again searching for the failsafe image.
00160  * -# If we still haven't found an image, print a message and halt. A chip reset
00161  *  will be needed to recover.
00162  *
00163  * The exact details of searching flash for an image are as follows:
00164  *
00165  * -# Print a message describing the image we are looking for.
00166  * -# Set our current NAND ECC block to zero.
00167  * -# Set our current state to LOOKING_FOR_HEADER.
00168  * -# Read 264 bytes from NAND. Increment our current NAND block.
00169  * -# Use the 8 bytes of ECC data to correct any errors.
00170  * -# If there are uncorrectable errors:
00171  *      -# If we are in state READING_DATA, print a message that a bad block was
00172  *       found and return to state LOOKING_FOR_HEADER.
00173  *      -# Go to step 4, reading more data.
00174  * -# If we are in stage LOOKING_FOR_HEADER and there is a valid header:
00175  *      -# Print a message showing where the header is and the size of the
00176  *       image.
00177  *      -# Lock the range of addresses needed for the image into L2.
00178  *      -# Set our L2 address to the one specified in the header.
00179  *      -# Copy the first 256 bytes of the image to the correct load
00180  *       address found in the header.
00181  *      -# Change to state READING_DATA.
00182  *      -# Increment our L2 address by 256.
00183  *      -# Go to step 4, reading more data.
00184  * -# If we are in stage READING_DATA:
00185  *      -# Print a message if errors were corrected by ECC.
00186  *      -# Increment our L2 address by 256.
00187  *      -# If we've gotten enough data for the image, check the image's CRC.
00188  *      -# If the CRC matches, then we have a valid image and we're done
00189  *       searching.
00190  *      -# If the CRC is invalid, then print a message, return to state
00191  *       LOOKING_FOR_HEADER, and reset our L2 address.
00192  * -# If the current ECC block is past the low 4MB of NAND, return failure.
00193  *
00194  * @section nand_boot_stage2_env 5. Stage 2 Execution Environment
00195  *
00196  * When stage 2 assumes control, it can assume the following execution
00197  * environment:
00198  *
00199  * -# Processor is in kernel mode with 64bit addressing enabled.
00200  * -# COP0 STATUS[BEV] is clear. Stage 2 should install exception vectors as
00201  *  soon as possible. Note that in order to modify COP0 EBASE, you must enable
00202  *  STATUS[BEV], change the value, and clear STATUS[BEV].
00203  * -# The UART is up and running in fifo mode with the baud rate set.
00204  * -# The stage 2 code is locked into L2 and index aliasing is enabled.
00205  * -# Icache prefetching is disabled.
00206  * -# CVMSEG is enabled and set to 54 lines.
00207  *
00208  * @section nand_boot_stage2_resp 6. Stage 2 Boot Responsibilities
00209  *
00210  * Stage 2 must perform the following operations before transferring control to
00211  * stage 3:
00212  *
00213  * -# Initialize dram.
00214  * -# Unlock and flush all of L2.
00215  * -# Change the size of CVMSEG to zero lines.
00216  * -# Disable access to CVMSEG.
00217  * -# Enable Icache prefetching.
00218  * -# Setup bootbus moveable regions on both the reset and EJTAG exception
00219  *  vectors.
00220  *
00221  * @section nand_boot_stage3_env 7. Stage 3 Execution Environment
00222  *
00223  * Stage 3 will begin executing at whatever it's link address is with dram
00224  * initialized. All OCTEON specific features are disabled to maintain maximum
00225  * Mips compatibility. All of memory is available for use by stage 3.
00226  * 
00227  * This can also happen in the stage 2 bootloader since the stage 2 bootloader
00228  * contains most if not all of the features of the stage 3 bootloader.
00229  *
00230  * @section nand_boot_stage3_resp 8. Stage 3 Boot Responsibilities
00231  *
00232  * Stage 3 has no strict requirements for its processing. It may perform any
00233  * action such as initializing hardware, loading kernels, and booting secondary
00234  * cores. Although Cavium provides a fully featured U-boot based stage 3, this
00235  * stage may freely be replaced. For example, VxWorks ROMMON can be loaded
00236  * instead of U-boot.
00237  *
00238  * @section nand_boot_final 9. Final Notes
00239  *
00240  * The three stage design of the OCTEON NAND boot process was designed
00241  * to maximize flexibility with the final boot loader and minimize the
00242  * hardware dependencies from stage 1. Dram setup in stage 2 allows for a
00243  * common dram setup to be used on a board even when multiple OSes require
00244  * different bootloaders. It is strongly recommended that stages 1 and 2 be used
00245  * with as few changes as possible. All application specific customization
00246  * should be placed in stage 3.
00247  *
00248  *
00249  * @section nand_boot_hands_on 10. NAND boot hands on
00250  *
00251  * This section will walk through bootstrapping a board with a blank NAND flash
00252  * chip using a Macraigor EJTAG probe and the OCTEON remote utilities.  This is a multi-step
00253  * process that will result in stage1 and stage2 being burned into NAND flash using
00254  * the OCTEON proprietary ECC encoding, and stage3 written to a JFFS2 filesystem using
00255  * standard NAND ECC.  U-boot can write stage1/stage2 and read stage3, and Linux is used
00256  * to create and write stage3 into the JFFS2 filesystem.  The specific examples below
00257  * show the process for an EBT5200 board, and are run the the base directory of the OCTEON SDK
00258  * install.
00259  *
00260  *
00261  * 1) Build NAND stage1.  This is in the OCTEON-SDK/bootloader/nand-boot directory.  Type 'make'
00262  * in this directory to build stage1.  We will use the nand-boot.bin that is
00263  * built here.  Stage1 should not require any modifications unless a new flash
00264  * device needs to be supported.
00265  *
00266  * 2) Connect the EJTAG probe to the board, and power them on.  Set the OCTEON_REMOTE_PROTOCOL
00267  * environment variable to "MACRAIGOR:probe_name_or_address,1000".  This will configure
00268  * the oct-remote* utilities to use the specified probe.  Connect to UART 0 of the target board with a terminal program.  Stage1 will
00269  * display boot progress over the UART.  Stage2 and the generic RAM based bootloader will boot to a u-boot prompt on the UART.
00270  *
00271  * 3) Boot the board using the generic board type.  The DIMM SPD addresses must be specified on
00272  * the command line, and the board delay may be required. (The default board delay value should support many boards,
00273  * but some will require a different value.)
00274 @verbatim
00275 oct-remote-boot --ddr0spd=0x50 --ddr0spd=0x51  --board=generic
00276 @endverbatim
00277  * Note that this may take a long period of time.  On an ebb6300 board with 1 DIMM installed it takes 1 hour.
00278  * 
00279  * 4) Load the nand_boot.bin over EJTAG, and burn it to address 0 in NAND.  Any errors will be reported on the serial port.
00280 @verbatim
00281 oct-remote-load 0 bootloader/nand-boot/nand-boot.bin
00282 oct-remote-bootcmd "octnand write 0"
00283 @endverbatim
00284  * 5) Load the stage2 bootloader and burn it into flash.  Here we use the generic stage2 that
00285  * has been compiled for the EBT5200 board.  Any errors will be reported on the serial port.
00286 @verbatim
00287 oct-remote-load 0 target/bin/u-boot-octeon_generic_nand_stage2.bin
00288 oct-remote-bootcmd "bootloaderupdate"
00289 @endverbatim
00290  * The 'bootloaderupdate' command finds a blank space in the low 4 Mbytes of flash and burns the stage2 image.  This image
00291  * has a header that stage1 searches for and uses to validate the image before running it.  At this point the board should boot
00292  * to the stage2 prompt after being reset:
00293 @verbatim
00294 Octeon nand#(stage2)
00295 @endverbatim
00296  * 6) Now we are ready to create the  JFFS2 filesystem.  To do this, Linux must be booted on the board, and the stage3 bootloader must
00297  * be available to Linux once booted.  If the networking works under Linux on the board, the tftp utilities in the embedded root filesystem
00298  * can be used to transfer the file over.  Alternatively, the stage3 bootloader binary can be built into the embedded root filesystem - this will be described here, as it
00299  * does not depend on networking on the target board.  The generic ram based bootloader, u-boot-octeon_generic_ram.bin, will be the stage 3 bootloader in this example.
00300  * - Make a directory named 'user-include' in the linux/embedded_rootfs directory, and copy the stage3 bootloader there.  For this example,
00301  * we will use the generic RAM bootloader as the stage3 bootloader.
00302  * - build the Linux kernel with the embedded root filesystem.
00303  * - Load and boot the resulting Linux kernel.  Note that the loading will take a while over EJTAG (10+ minutes).  If networking is functional in the RAM based u-boot
00304  * on the target board, tftp is a much quicker alternative.
00305 @verbatim
00306 oct-remote-boot --ddr0spd=0x50 --ddr0spd=0x51  --board=generic
00307 oct-remote-load 0 linux/kernel/linux//vmlinux.64
00308 oct-remote-bootcmd "bootoctlinux 0 mtdparts=octeon_nand0:4m(reserved)ro,8m(jffs2)"
00309 @endverbatim
00310  * - The stage3 bootloader from the user-include directory will show up in the root directory of the embedded rootfs.
00311  * - Mount the jffs2 partition, and copy the bootloader to it, then unmount the partition.  In the above example, the JFFS2 partition is /dev/mtdblock1.  The mapping of MTD partitions to device
00312  * nodes is listed in the '/proc/mtd' file.
00313 @verbatim
00314 mount -t jffs2 /dev/mtdblock1 /mnt
00315 cp u-boot-octeon_generic_ram.bin /mnt
00316 umount /mnt
00317 @endverbatim
00318  *
00319  * 7) Now we need to verify that stage2 can read stage3, and update the 'bootcmd' environment variable in stage2 to start stage3 automatically.  We will now reset the board,
00320  * and let it come to the stage 2 prompt.  At the stage 2 prompt, issue the following commands to list the files in the jffs2 filesystem.
00321 @verbatim
00322 jffs2chpart jffs2
00323 jffs2ls
00324 @endverbatim
00325  *
00326  * 8) Now try manually loading/starting stage 3.  The generic RAM based u-boot expects to be loaded at 0x100000, so that is where we load it.  Once it is loaded, we jump
00327  * to the start address with the 'go' command.
00328 @verbatim
00329 jffs2load 0x100000 u-boot-octeon_generic_ram.bin
00330 go 0x100000
00331 @endverbatim
00332  * The RAM based bootloader should boot at this point, and we should get the following prompt.
00333 @verbatim
00334 Octeon generic(ram)#
00335 @endverbatim
00336 
00337  * 9) Now we need to set the 'bootcmd' environment variable in stage2 so that stage3 is booted automatically.  Reset the board and let it come to the stage2 prompt.
00338 @verbatim
00339 Octeon nand#(stage2) setenv bootcmd 'jffs2chpart jffs2;jffs2load 0x100000 u-boot-octeon_generic_ram.bin;go 0x100000'
00340 Octeon nand#(stage2) saveenv
00341 @endverbatim
00342 
00343  * 10) When reset, the board should now boot to stage 3.
00344  *
00345 @verbatim
00346 Octeon generic(ram)#
00347 @endverbatim
00348  *
00349  *
00350  *
00351  *
00352  *
00353  *
00354  *
00355  * @section nand_boot_impl_notes 10.1 NAND boot implementation notes
00356  *
00357  * - MTD partitioning of the NAND flash is required for creating the JFFS2 filesystem under linux, and is highly desirable
00358  * for read-only access from u-boot stage2 as well.  JFFS2 will attempt to use any erased block it is allowed to use, so the low
00359  * 4 MBytes must be excluded when writing, otherwise blocks from this area may be used by JFFS2.  Also, the u-boot JFFS2 implementation
00360  * is fairly slow, and scanning large partitions can take a long time.  If possible, the JFFS2 partition that contains stage3 should be kept small.
00361  * The 'mtdids' and 'mtdparts' environment variables are used by u-boot to control the MTD partitioning that u-boot uses.  Please see the environment section
00362  * on the bootloader documentation page for more information on these and other environment variables.
00363  * - Parameter passing between stage2 and stage3 is done by stage2 placing a u-boot environment structure in DRAM at a fixed location.  The next stage
00364  * can validate this (it includes a CRC) and get any values of interest from it.  The structure is simply a CRC followed by a series of NUL terminated strings.
00365  * Two consecutive NULs terminate the list of environment variables.  The only value that is passed by default is the DRAM size, as stage3 needs to get this
00366  * from stage2 (Or alternatively, it can query the DIMMS and re-calculate this value, but getting it from stage2 is simpler.)  Additional information can be easily
00367  * added to the environment before starting stage3.
00368  *
00369  *
00370  *
00371  * @section nand_porting_stage2 11. Porting stage2 to a new board
00372  * The second stage of the NAND boot process is responsible for two things: configuring the DRAM
00373  * controller(s), and starting the final (stage3) bootloader.  As such it needs the details of the
00374  * DRAM configuration for the board, and it needs to be able to read stage 3 from the NAND flash part.
00375  * The "octeon_generic_nand_stage2_config" is a stage2 bootloader configuration that can be easily modified to support a new board.
00376  * (If the NAND flash for the board in question is not supported by u-boot, support will need to be added.  This NAND support should be developed using
00377  * the 'octeon_generic_ram_config' DRAM based u-boot configuration as this provides the simplest development environment for u-boot changes.)
00378  *
00379  * The following changes must be made:
00380  *  -# update the DRAM_SOCKET_CONFIGURATION \#define to reflect the DIMM SPD addresses on the board.  This is required for the
00381  *    DRAM initialization code.
00382  *  -# Change the BOARD_DELAY parameter to an appropriate value for the board.  This is a board dependent value that depends on the board layout. (Additionally, the
00383  *      LMC_DELAY_* parameters should be set once the correct values are determined.)
00384  *  -# Set the 'bootcmd' environment variable in the octeon_generic_nand_stage2.h header file.  This command will load and start execution of the stage3 (final) bootloader.
00385  *
00386  * The following changes should be made:
00387  *  -# Add a new board type to cvmx-app-init.h, and update the NAND_STAGE2_BOARD_TYPE define to use the new board type.  This allows per-board customization
00388  *      within the stage2 bootloader if other changes are required.
00389  *  -# Adjust the default NAND partitioning as required.
00390  *
00391  *
00392  *
00393  *
00394  */
00395
